Award.AwardTitle: Mechanical and Manufacturing Technologies for Energy and Sustainability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Connecticut Business and Industry Association (CBIA) and Gateway Community College (GWCC) are implementing the Mechanical and Manufacturing Technologies for Energy and Sustainability (MET2) Program. MET2 engages a diverse group of community college and university students and faculty in industry-driven projects focused on mechanical/manufacturing engineering technology, with emphasis on energy and sustainability. The project cuts across technologies such as mechatronics, nanotechnology and green manufacturing, and brings together numerous industry and education partners to ensure broad stakeholder representation and involvement. MET2 develops and strengthens the innovation pipeline from high schools to community colleges and universities, leading ultimately to the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) technician workforce. The project is designed to attract and engage students from groups that are underrepresented in STEM disciplines and to foster their interest in the pursuit of careers in technology and engineering. In addition, MET2 includes veterans who are provided with a supportive Veterans Oasis at the participating community colleges.

MET2 integrates professional skills, including entrepreneurial skills, leadership development and innovation, in industry-driven problem-based projects. It expands on the Life Support and Sustainable Living (LSSL) Program, a successful NSF-funded program that received the ATE High Impact Technology Exchange Conference's Innovative Program Award at the 2012 HI-TEC Conference in Denver, Colorado.

The primary goals of MET2 are to: (1) develop an engineering, technology and business skills-based curriculum including business model development and professional skills, for engineering and technical disciplines; (2) engage community college and university students in a team-based learning environment with the opportunity to solve real-world challenges, from conceptualization to final design; (3) engage technical high school students in an outreach program to create and strengthen a career pipeline in technology and engineering disciplines; and (4) provide professional development for technical high school, community college and university faculty on technical and professional skills. Assessment and evaluation include input from students, faculty and industry stakeholders to determine the extent to which the program is successful in creating networking opportunities that connect the program to the workforce; implementing mentoring activities that positively impact participants' formal engineering and technology academic performance; leading to sustained entrepreneurial activities in engineering and technology programs in Connecticut's technical high schools, community colleges and partner universities; and increasing enrollment of underrepresented students in engineering and technology programs at Connecticut's community colleges and universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary: A partnership of community colleges, universities, business associations, and Connecticut manufacturers implemented the Mechanical and Manufacturing Technologies for Energy and Sustainability (MET²) Program. The Program engaged a diverse group of community college and university students as well as faculty in industry driven technology and engineering technology projects with particular emphasis on energy and sustainability. Professional, business and entrepreneurial skills were an integral facet of this program in order to provide Connecticut industry with a highly skilled workforce capable of interacting with others effectively. Successful results from the MET² Program were based on the following goals: (1) Design and develop the MET² team – based curriculum, project planning, professional skills and intellectual property management for technical education; (2) Engage community college and university students in MET² team-based learning environment and industry projects; (3) Engage technical high school students to create and strengthen the career pipeline in Technology and Engineering disciplines; and (4) Provide professional development for faculty and teachers in the application of MET² curriculum, both online and face-to-face.

Intellectual Merits: The MET² Program had a significant transformative effect on 171 students. The program was designed to provide students with a real life employment experience. Minority students made up 45% of the total participants and female students represented 23%. Students evaluated the Program with an average summative evaluation of 4.8 on a scale of 1.0 to 5.0, with 5.0 being extremely satisfied. Approximately 95% of the community college participants who completed the program transferred to a university in a related technology or engineering field. The project attracted a significant number of active partners who donated time, equipment and other resources that added to the Program’s success. Students participated in self-managed teams and were required to complete monthly and comprehensive annual reports. Thirty real-world projects were implemented and included work such as the latest space suit for NASA; a prosthetic arm for children; a permeameter device and 3D printed fracture networks for the U.S. Geological Survey; a bio-reactive ankle bracelet;  an electronic safety harness device for construction workers; a modular manufacturing facility; and a life-raft using smart fabrics for the U.S. Coast Guard Academy.

Broader Impacts: The MET² Program developed and strengthened the innovation pipeline from inner-city high schools to community colleges and universities, and ultimately to the workplace. The humanistic aspects of many projects helped to attract and retain females and underrepresented students in technology and engineering related disciplines. Summer workshops were instrumental in disseminating curricula to STEM high school and community college faculty who integrated MET² best practices into their classrooms and labs at their home institutions. MET² staff and students participated in regional and national professional conferences including the NSF ATE Principal Investigator, HITEC, National Association for Workforce Improvement, and the Society of Mechanical Engineers conferences where they shared their ideas, experiences and prototypes, thus improving their people, networking and presentation skills. Upon completing the MET² program, students significantly enhanced their leadership; teamwork and entrepreneurial skills while fine-tuning and utilizing their classroom knowledge, thus preparing them for entry into technology and engineering positions upon graduation.


Last Modified: 11/02/2018
Modified by: John Birch
